titleStmt.title: Robust Adaptive Neural Tracking Control for a Class of Perturbed Uncertain Nonlinear Systems With State Constraints

affiliation.orgName: School of Computer Science and Engineering, and Center for Robotics
University of Electronic Science and Technology of China
Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
University of Electronic Science and Technology of China
University of Science and Technology of Beijing

analytic.title: Robust Adaptive Neural Tracking Control for a Class of Perturbed Uncertain Nonlinear Systems With State Constraints

biblStruct.note: received August 15, 2015; revised October 27, 2015; accepted November 22, 2015.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: In this paper, we deal with the problem of tracking control for a class of uncertain nonlinear systems in strictfeedback form subject to completely unknown system nonlinearities, hard constraints on full states, and unknown time-varying bounded disturbances. Integral barrier Lyapunov functionals are constructed to handle the unknown affine control gains (g(•)) with state constraints simultaneously. This removes the need on the knowledge of control gains for control design and avoids the conservative step of transforming original state constraints into new bounds on tracking errors. Neural networks (NNs) are used to approximate the unknown continuous packaged functions. To enhance the robustness, adapting parameters are developed to compensate the unknown bounds on NNs approximations and external disturbances. Design parameters-dependent feasibility conditions are formulated as sufficient conditions for the existence of feasible design parameters to guarantee the state constraints, and an offline constrained optimization step is proposed to obtain the optimal design parameters prior to the implementation of the proposed control. It is proved that the proposed control can guarantee the semiglobal uniform ultimate boundedness of all signals in closed-loop system, all states are ensured to remain in the predefined constrained state space, and tracking error converges to an adjustable neighborhood of the origin by choosing appropriate design parameters. Simulations are performed to validate the proposed control.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: T HE state constraints are a major concern in both prac- tical systems and control theories, as the violation of constraints on state variables may degrade the performance or even cause instability, and the mathematical system model is usually only valid in certain constrained state regions. Furthermore, practical systems are usually operated near the constraint boundaries or limits to pursue high economic efficiency [1]. The constraints boundaries may be violated due to potential external disturbances or various kinds of system uncertainties. Driven by these problems, the research on the handling of state constraints in the presence of uncertainties and disturbance is important and has gained an increasingly research attention.

In the past decades, numerous significant results have been proposed to address the state constraints in control systems [2]- [6]. The idea of invariance control is to render the constraint admissible set being positively invariant, such that any initial state trajectory in the constraint admissible set would remain in it, and it has been applied to nonlinear systems by employing a switching scheme between nominal controller in the admissible set and invariance controller on the constraint boundary [2]. In the framework of optimization scheme, model predictive control obtains the control signal for constrained systems by repeatedly solving an online finite horizon open-loop optimal control problem [3], and reference governor ensures the constraint satisfaction by modifying the reference signals through online optimal algorithm [4]. However, the online optimization-based methods may suffer from the heavy online computation burden as the solution should be obtained between two sampling time.

Recently, inspired by the idea of reshaping a control Lyapunov function, barrier Lyapunov functions (BLFs) have been developed to guarantee the output and state constraints satisfaction for various kinds of nonlinear systems by state feedback [7]- [10] and output feedback [11], [12]. With respect to the conventional Lyapunov functions (e.g., quadratic forms) [13] that are radially unbounded for global stability, a BLF is defined to be positive definite on an open region and approaches infinity whenever its arguments approach some limits [7]. By ensuring the boundedness of the BLFs along the system solutions, the violation of constraints can be prevented. One distinguished feature for BLFs-based control is that the control design is constructive based on the Lyapunov 2168-2216 c 2016 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.

direct method and the computation burden is greatly reduced compared with online optimization methods. Motivated by these above properties, the BLFs-based control has been developed for the practical systems with constraints requirement, including the electrostatic microactuators demanding no contact between movable and fixed electrodes in [14], flexible systems with boundary constraint in [15]- [17], and constrained robotic manipulator in [18] and [19]. Given the unknown system dynamics and external disturbances, the control design for constrained systems is becoming more difficult, due to the lack of knowledge on system dynamics for control design and the possible violation of state constraints because of these unknown uncertainties. To handle the system uncertainties, an effective approach is to employ the neural networks (NNs) or fuzzy logic systems (FLSs) to approximate these unknown system dynamics [20]- [24], particularly for the unstructured uncertainties, due to its general approximation capabilities of any smooth nonlinear functions to any desired accuracy over a compact set [25], [26]. Based on Lyapunov synthesis, to overcome the restrictions of matching conditions in uncertain nonlinear systems, the approximation-based methods are always combined with the recursive backstepping scheme to handle the canonical uncertain nonlinear systems without the matching conditions [27]- [35], and the explosion of complexity in conventional backstepping scheme by requiring repeated differentiations can be avoided using the so-called dynamic surface control [36], [37], and these adaptive approximation control schemes have been also applied to address other particular systems, including robotic manipulator [38], [39], permanent magnet synchronous motors [40], [41], time-delay systems [42]- [44], and multiagent systems [45]. Recently, the adaptive fuzzy and NN control design methods have been developed for various class of nonlinear systems with both constraints and unknown dynamics. For example, [37] first proposed a tracking error constrained adaptive fuzzy output-feedback control method for multi-input multi-output nonlinear systems, and the adaptive NN constrained control schemes have also been proposed for output-feedback system with unity control gains in [11], strict-feedback system with known control gains in [46], or known NN bounds in [47]. However, it is still not clear on how to address the full states constrained nonlinear systems with unknown control gains subject to unknown disturbances.
Based on the above analysis, the main contributions of this paper can be concluded as follows.

1) Compared with the conventional barrier Lyapunov functions utilized in [7]- [9], [11], [46], and [48]- [50], novel integral barrier Lyapunov functionals (iBLFs) are proposed here to handle the unknown affine control gains and constraints on states together, for which the control gain functions can be relaxed to be unknown, and a conservative mapping of original constrains to new bounds on error space is avoided. 2) By the utilization of the proposed iBLFs, the number of conditions in offline optimization scheme for feasibility check is greatly reduced and initial states can be relaxed to the whole constrained space.

3) The unknown packaged functions in desired control are approximated by NNs and adapting parameters are incorporated in the adaptive NN control to estimate the unknown bounds on NN approximations and external disturbances. The rest of this paper is organized as follows. Section II formulates the control problem. Then, Section III illustrates the main idea through a second-order system. Section IV gives the adaptive NN control design. Section V presents the offline feasibility check method. Section VI gives an application of the proposed control. The last section concludes this paper.

div.head: A. System Dynamics
div.p: Consider the following single-input single-output strictfeedback nonlinear systems with unknown time-varying external disturbance:
div.formula: ẋi (t) = f i (x i (t)) + g i (x i (t))x i+1 (t) + d i (t) i = 1, 2, . . . , n -1 ẋn (t) = f n (x n (t)) + g n (x n (t))u(t) + d n (t) y(t) = x 1 (t), t ∈ R +(1)
div.p: where
div.formula: := {x ∈ R n : |x i (t)| < k c i , i = 1, . . . , n, t > 0} ⊂ R n provided |x i (0)| < k c i and |y d (t)| < k c 1 ,
div.p: where k c i are positive constants, which represent the predefined constraints on the states. If only x 1 is required to remain in χ , the above problem is reduced to control of output-constrained nonlinear systems.

Remark 1: The state constraints considered in this paper, i.e., |x i (t)| < k c i , are based on the worst-case scenario. The desired value of constraints can be specified according to practical problems' requirements. Furthermore, the constraints k c i should be ensured to satisfy k c i > |α i-1 (κ 1 , . . . , κ i-1 )|, i = 1, . . . , n, in which the α i-1 's are the virtual stabilizing functions to be designed, α 0 is the desired trajectory, and κ i are design parameters. Such a requirement is formulated in (46) as sufficient conditions for the state constraints to be satisfied under the proposed control, and all states in the constrained set share the same design parameters. These conditions are to guarantee that the Lyapunov candidate functionals are positive definite in the constrained set and depend on the design parameters κ i once the state constraints k c i are determined and initial states are chosen in the constrained state space. If the states are to be constrained in a small set, such a control may not exist. Given a set of constraints k c i , it is preferred to choose sufficient large control gains to achieve good tracking performance, but increasing control gains lead to larger α i-1 's and thus may violate the conditions (46). The tradeoff is formulated as the feasibility check proposed in Section V to satisfy the feasibility conditions and maximize the control performance by selecting the optimal control parameters.
Assumption 1: The unknown time-varying disturbances
div.formula: d i (t), i = 1, . . . , n, are bounded as |d i (t)| < D * i , ∀t ≥ 0 with D * i ∈ R + as the unknown constant.
div.p: Remark 2: In reality, the energy of external disturbance d i (t) is always finite and hence it is reasonable to assume d i (t) is bounded by an unknown constant. Similar conditions have been also assumed in [51] and [52].
Assumption 2 [7]: For any k c 1 > 0, there exit positive constants A 0 , Y i , i = 1, . . . , n, such that the desired trajectory y d and its time derivative satisfy
div.formula: |y d (t)| ≤ A 0 < k c 1 , |y (i) d (t)| < Y i
div.p: , ∀t ≥ 0, and i = 1, . . . , n. We also denote

Remark 3: The above assumption on the desired trajectory has been commonly employed in the existing trajectory tracking literatures (see [7], [8], for example). In addition, the desired trajectory can be generated from the bounded reference model [53]- [55], which can output smooth and bounded reference signal to track.
Assumption 3: The signs of g i (x i ), i = 1, 2, . . . , n, are known, and there exist known continuous functions ḡi (x i ) and positive constants g i,0 > 0 such that 0
div.formula: < g i,0 ≤ |g i (x i )| ≤ ḡi (x i ) < ∞ for |x j | < k c j , j = 1, 2 . . . , i.
div.p: Without loss of generality, we further assume that the g i (x i ) are all positive for

Remark 4: Assumption 3 indicates the boundedness of control gain functions, and it is reasonable in the sense that g i (x i ) being away from zeros are the controllable conditions of system (1), which has been made in many control schemes [13], [56]. Similar conditions have been also assumed in [7] and [8]; however, in this paper, we do not require the functions g i (x i ) to be known, and hence Assumption 3 is more general than the ones in existing literatures. Furthermore, for practical systems, it is not difficult to determine the bounds of g i (x i ) by choosing ḡi (x i ) large enough. And in this paper, we do not discuss the condition on the signs of g i (x i ) crossing zero. It should be noted that, in this paper, the lower bounds, i.e., g i,0 , are only required for analytical purposes and their true values are not necessarily to be known.

div.head: B. Radial Basis Function Neural Networks
div.p: Due to the property of universal approximation capabilities over a compact set, the radial basis function (RBF) NNs have been widely used in the control design for uncertain nonlinear systems [57]. In this paper, the RBF NNs are adopted and modeled as the following form:
div.formula: h nn (Z) = W T S(Z) (2)
div.p: where Z = [z 1 , . . . , z q ] ∈ z ⊂ R q and W = [w 1 , w 2 , . . . , w l ] T ∈ R l are the NN input vector and weight vector, respectively, the NN node number l > 1; and S(Z) = [s 1 (Z), . . . , s l (Z)] T , with s i (Z) being chosen as the commonly used Gaussian functions, which have the form
div.formula: s i (Z) = exp -(Z -μ i ) T (Z -μ i ) η 2 i (3
div.p: where
div.formula: μ i = [μ i1 , μ i2 , . . . , μ iq ]
div.p: T are the centers of the receptive field and η i is the width of the Gaussian function.
It has been proved that, provided sufficient number of NN nodes l, W T S(Z) can approximate any continuous h(Z) : R q → R over a compact set Z ⊂ R q to any desired accuracy as
where W * is the ideal unknown constant weight vector and (Z) is the unknown approximation error and bounded over the compact set. The ideal weight vector W * is defined as
div.formula: W * := arg min W∈R l sup Z∈ z h(Z) -W T S(Z) . (5
div.p: Assumption 4 [53]: For a given smooth function h(Z), there exist ideal unknown constant weight vector W * such that | | ≤ * with * ∈ R + being unknown constant for all Z ∈ z .
For the RBF NN using Gaussian basis functions, the following lemma gives an upper bound on the norm of the basis function vector S(Z).
Lemma 1 [58]: For the Gaussian RBF NN (2) and (3), let ρ min i =j ||μ i -μ j || and q be the dimension of input Z, and η be the width of Gaussian function. Then ||S(Z)|| is upper bounded as

where s * is an unknown positive constant and independent of the NN inputs Z and the NN node number l. Remark 5: The RBF NNs utilized in this paper can be replaced by any other online approximators, such as FLS, wavelet networks, and polynomials.

div.head: C. Integral Barrier Lyapunov Candidate Functionals
div.p: Consider the integral barrier Lyapunov candidate functionals given by
div.formula: V x i (z i (t), α i-1 (t)) = z i 0 β i σ k 2 c i k 2 c i -(σ + α i-1 ) 2 dσ (7
div.p: where
div.formula: z i = x i -α i-1 , i = 1, . . . , n, α 0 = y d , and α 1 , . . . , α n-1 are continuously differentiable functions satisfying |α i | ≤ A i < k c i+1 for positive constants A i , i = 0, 1, . . . , n -1. β i (x i ) = ḡi (x i )/g i (x i ) ≥ 1, i = 1, . . . , n.
div.p: Since α i-1 also depend on system states, then iBLF candidates V x i (7) are directly respect to state variables and are positive definite, continuously differentiable and satisfy the decrescent condition in the set
div.formula: |x i | < k c i , for i = 1, . . . , n. Let σ = θ z i , we obtain z 2 i 2 ≤ V x i ≤ z 2 i g i0 1 0 ḡi (x i-1 , σ + α i-1 )θ k 2 c i k 2 c i -(θ z i + sgn(z i )A i-1 ) 2 dθ (8)
div.p: which is useful for proving the uniform stability. According to Assumption 3, we have
div.formula: 1 ≤ β i (x i-1 , σ + α i-1 ) ≤ ḡi (x i-1 , σ + α i-1 ) g i0 . (9
div.p: For the convenience of analysis, we let β * i := (ḡ i /g i0 ) and it is easy to see that 1 ≤ β i ≤ β * i and β * i ∈ R + is a bounded positive constant and the true values are not necessarily to be known and depend on the choice of ḡi .
Lemma 2: The functional V x i , i = 1, . . . , n, described in (7), satisfy
div.formula: V x i ≤ β * i k 2 c i z 2 i k 2 c i -x 2 i (10
for |x i | < k c i . Proof: See Appendix A.
div.p: Remark 6: In the previous works using iBLF [46], [50], the affine control gains are required to be known for the control design. However, for many practical systems [59], it is often difficult or even impossible to obtain the exact control gain functions and it is always a challenging problem for adaptive control of uncertain nonlinear systems with unknown control gains [60]. To remove the restriction, inspired by the work in [61], we modify the previous functionals by multiplying an additional term involving unknown affine control gains and its known bound (β(•) = ḡ(•)/g(•)), thus the unknown control gains and state constraints can be handled at the same time. Therefore, it is nontrivial to extend the previous BLF-based control designs to the systems with unknown control gains, in which the construction of appropriate barrier functions for constrained systems is the key step.
The following lemma is used for establishing state constrains satisfaction and performance bounds.
Lemma 3: For any positive constants
div.formula: k c i , i = 1, . . . , n, let χ := {x ∈ R n : |x i (t)| < k c i , i = 1, . . . , n, t ≥ 0} ⊂ R n and N := R l × χ ⊂ R l+n be open sets. Consider the system η = h(t, η) (11
div.p: where η := [ω, x] T ∈ N , and h : R + ×N → R l+n is piecewise continuous in t and locally Lipschitz in z, uniformly in t, on
div.formula: R + × N . Let χ i := {x i ∈ R : |x i (t)| < k c i , t ≥ 0} ⊂ R, suppose
div.p: that there exist functions U : R l → R + and V i : χ i → R + , i = 1, . . . , n, are continuously differentiable and positive definite in their respective domains, such that
div.formula: V i (x i ) → ∞ as |x i | → k c i (12) γ 1 ( ω ) ≤ U(ω) ≤ γ 2 ( ω ) (13
div.p: where γ 1 and γ 2 are class
div.formula: K ∞ functions. Let V(η) := n i=1 V i (x i ) + U(ω) and x i (0) belong to the set χ . If the inequality holds V = ∂V ∂η h ≤ -μV + λ (14
div.p: in the set η ∈ N and μ and λ are positive constants, then ω remains bounded and x(t) ∈ χ, ∀t ∈ [0, ∞).

Proof: The conditions on h ensure the existence and uniqueness of a maximal solution η(t) on the time interval [0, τ max ). Provided the fact that x(0) ∈ χ , we known that V i (x i (0)), i = 1, . . . , n, and thus V(η(0)) exist. Integrating both sides of inequality (14), it is obtained that
div.formula: V(η(t)) ≤ V(η(0)) + λ/μ, ∀t ∈ [0, τ max ). From V(η) := n i=1 V i (x i ) + U(ω) and the fact that V i (x i ), i = 1, . . . , n are positive functions, we have that each V i (x i (t)) is bounded ∀t ∈ [0, τ max ]. As V i (x i ) → ∞ only if x i → k c i , we can conclude, from the boundedness of V i (x i (t)), that |x i (t)| < k c i , ∀t ∈ [0, τ max ). Hence, there is a compact subset K ⊂ N such that the maximal solution of (3) satisfies η(t) ∈ K, ∀t ∈ [0, τ max ). We then have that η(t) is defined ∀t ∈ [0, ∞). It follows that x(t) ∈ χ, ∀t ∈ [0, ∞).
div.p: This completes the proof.

div.head: III. CONTROL DESIGN FOR SECOND-ORDER SYSTEMS WITH UNKNOWN CONTROL GAINS
div.p: In this section, to demonstrate the major advantage in the proposed solution, i.e., the unknown control gains and state constraints are addressed at the same time, we consider the control of the second-order system with unknown control gains for illustration, and show that the proposed control is able to guarantee that the state constraints are not violated without knowing g i (•), i = 1, . . . , n. The general case of systems with completely unknown system functions and disturbances are addressed in Section IV, where we give the detailed adaptive NN control designs for high-order systems. Consider the system

where f 1 (x 1 ) and f 2 (x 1 , x 2 ) are known drift functions and g 1 (x 1 ) and g 2 (x 1 , x 2 ) are unknown control gains; u ∈ R is the control input, and x 1 and x 2 ∈ R are the states required to satisfy |x

div.p: k c 2 being positive constants. The backstepping design is as following.

As β 1 = ḡ1 /g 1 , the stabilizing function is designed as

div.p: and it means that the iBLF candidate ( 23) is bounded by a positive constant along the solution of system (15) by the proposed control. Furthermore, using Lemma 3 and the property V(x) → ∞ as |x| → k c , we obtain that V 1 (x 1 (t), x 2 (t)) is bounded, and it can be proved that the states x 1 (t) and x 1 (t) in system (15) remain in the constrained set, i.e., |x

Prior to the implementation of the proposed control, the feasibility check proposed in Section V should be performed to guarantee the feasibility condition of |α 1 | < k c 2 by choosing appropriate control parameters κ 1 . The check is formulated in an constrained optimization problem and can be performed by MATLAB routine fmincon.m to obtain an optimal value of κ 1 . Given the state constraints k c 1 and k c 2 , by solving the constrained optimization problem, the obtained control parameter κ 1 is feasible in ensuring the output tracking and state constraints satisfaction.

A concern is that feasibility condition |α 1 | < k c 2 may be violated when the state x 1 approaches the constraint k c 1 . However, by choosing appropriate design parameter κ 1 to satisfy |α 1 (0)| < k c 2 , we can obtain |α 1 (t)| < k c 2 , ∀t > 0 by using the designed control. As we have proved that, under the proposed control, we have |x 2 (t)| < k c 2 , ∀t > 0, and also since
div.formula: |z 2 (t)+α 1 (t)| = |x 2 (t)|, we can obtain |α 1 (t)| < k c 2 .
div.p: This result can be also extended to high-order system if the states can be proved to remain in the constrained set by the designed control. The generated large control action when states approaches the constraint boundary is the result of BLFs property V(x) → ∞ as |x| → k c , and such a property is actually key for the BLF-based control to guarantee constraints.

div.head: IV. ADAPTIVE NN CONTROL DESIGN
div.p: FOR HIGH-ORDER SYSTEMS In this section, we present the control design and stability analysis for the original high-order system (1) with unknown system functions and external disturbances. As the drift functions f i 's are unknown, then the packaged functions h i (Z i ) are not available, and the model-based control law is not desirable. To overcome the difficulty, the RBF NNs are incorporated in the control to estimate unknown packaged functions, and adapting parameters are constructed in the control to estimate and compensate the unknown bounds on NNs and disturbances. The system diagram using the proposed control is demonstrated in Fig. 1.
By using the backstepping method [13], the control design has n steps and depends on the coordinates transformation:

. . , Ŵi-1 , p1 , . . . , pi-1 ), and i = 3, . . . , n. The dynamic variables z i , i = 1, . . . , n are the tracking errors, and the functions α i 's are the virtual stabilizing functions to be designed for the tracking error dynamics. Ŵi 's denote the estimation of unknown ideal weight vector W * i 's and we define the estimation error vectors Wi = Ŵi -W * i with Wi ≤ * w i . pi 's are the parameter estimations for p * i 's, which are the grouped unknown bounds of
div.formula: * n i + * w i s * n i +D * i β * i . pi = pi -p *
div.p: i are the parameter estimation errors. To this end, considering the following Lyapunov candidate functionals for control design:
div.formula: V = n i=1 V x i (z i , α i-1 ) + n i=1 1 2 p2 i (33
div.p: where V x i is defined in (7).
The time derivatives of V x i along the tracking error dynamics are given by
div.formula: Vx i (t) = β i k 2 c i z i k 2 c i -x 2 i ( f i + g i z i+1 + g i α i -αi-1 ) + ∂V x i ∂α i-1 αi-1 . (34
div.p: Using integration by parts and the substitution σ = θ z i , it yields
div.formula: ∂V x i ∂α i-1 = β i z i k 2 c i k 2 c i -x 2 i -z i ρ i (z i , α i-1 )(35)
div.p: and
div.formula: ρ i (z i , α i-1 ) = 1 0 β i (θ z i + α i-1 )k 2 c i k 2 c i -(θ z i + α i-1 ) 2 dθ. (36
div.p: By substituting z i = 0 into (36), we obtain
div.formula: ρ i (0, α i-1 ) = β i (α i-1 )k 2 c i k 2 c i -α 2 i-1 . (37
div.p: Since
div.formula: |α i-1 | < k c i can be guaranteed in Section V, ρ i (z i , α i-1 )
div.p: is well-defined in the neighborhood of z i = 0. According to the Lyapunov direct method, the stabilizing functions are designed as

div.p: where pi (0) ≥ 0, κ i > 0, i = T i > 0, σ w i > 0, σ p i > 0, and the σ modification terms are used to prevent the estimation from growing to large values and enhance the robustness to approximation errors and disturbances.
The following lemma gives the result on the boundedness of Ŵi .
Lemma 4 [62]: Under the update law (39), the Ŵi (t) is semiglobally uniformly bounded in the compact set

div.p: where S i (Z i ) ≤ s * n i , provided Ŵi (0) ∈ w i . Remark 7: Lemma 4 shows that the boundedness of NN weight estimation vectors can be guaranteed using the adaptive law (39). Hence, this paper obtains the controller by considering the functional (33) without the inclusion of NN estimation errors as usual.

In the following, we establish that the states x(t) remain in the constrained set χ, ∀t > 0, provided that x(0) ∈ χ , and the boundedness of all signals in the closed-loop system.
Theorem 1: Consider the closed-loop system consisting of system (1), controllers (38) with (42), and update laws (39) with (40), then for any bounded initial conditions x(0)

div.p: n j /σ w j ), j = 1, . . . , n}. Given the constraints k c i > 0, if there exist positive constants κ 1 , . . . , κ n-1 that satisfy the following feasibility conditions:
where |y d (t)| ≤ A 0 < k c 1 , then the following properties hold.
1) The error signals z i (t) and pi (t), i = 1, . . . , n are uniformly bounded in the compact set 1 defined by
and the errors will eventually (as time goes to infinity) converge to the compact set 2 defined by
div.formula: 2 := z i (t), pi (t) ∈ R lim t→∞ |z i (t)| ≤ 2C θ , lim t→∞ |p i (t)| ≤ 2C θ .(48)
div.p: 2) The state x(t) remain in the constrained set χ .

3) The intermediate stabilization functions α i (t), i = 1, . . . , n -1 and the control input u(t) are bounded, ∀t ≥ 0. Proof: See Appendix B. Remark 8: Compared with previous works in [7], [8], and [11], the proposed control scheme in this paper handles the constraints on x i , i = 1, . . . , n directly, and the conventional conservative steps of transforming constraints k c i into new bounds k b i on tracking errors z i are removed. And accordingly, the initial states can be chosen as |x i (0)| < k c i , not just a subset of constrained space as in [7] and [8]. With respect to [46] and [50], the system dynamics in (1) including the drift dynamics and control gains are relaxed to be totally unknown and not necessary to be assumed as linearly parameterizable. Furthermore, the unknown bounds on NN approximations are also adaptively estimated, which reduces the conservatism in [47] on requiring these bounds to be exactly known for control design.

Remark 9: The stability guaranteed in this paper is the semiglobally uniformly ultimately bounded in the sense that provided the initial values of the constrained sets, desired trajectory, and NN estimation weights are chosen belong to the admissible compact set , all signals in the closed-loop systems are bounded and error signals z i (t) and pi (t), i = 1, . . . , n converge to the final compact set 2 as time goes to infinity. And the size of final compact set 2 can be adjusted to smaller by making constant C smaller and constant θ larger. To make C small, we need choose the design parameters σ p i and δ i small; to make θ large, we need the κ i , ḡi and σ p i be large. However, using small σ p i and δ i may produce large NN estimation weights and adapting parameters, and choosing large κ i may lead to the increase in control input and excite unmodeled dynamics. Furthermore, to ensure the IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON SYSTEMS, MAN, AND CYBERNETICS: SYSTEMS feasibility conditions (46), the design parameters κ i cannot be selected arbitrarily large. Accordingly, the design parameters should be appropriated selected to ensure good tracking performance.

div.head: V. FEASIBILITY CHECK
div.p: In this section, the feasibility check is proposed to obtain a set of optimal design parameters for the proposed control to ensure the output tracking without violating any of the state constraints. The feasibility conditions are formulated as sufficient conditions (46) in Theorem 1. Provided the determined state constraints and initial conditions, these conditions (46) can be satisfied by choosing appropriate design parameters κ i , i = 1, . . . , n.

Give the output tracking objective, it is usually preferred to choose large control parameters κ i to enhance the robustness and achieve good tracking performance, but it may increase the bounds A i defined in (45), making it more difficult to satisfy the feasibility conditions (46). Hence, such a tradeoff between the performance and the feasibility satisfaction is formulated as a nonlinear constrained optimization problem, which is solved offline, prior to the actual implementation.

Following the works in [8] and [50], this paper checks the feasibility condition (46) by solving an offline optimizing problem, aiming at maximizing the control gains to achieve better tracking performance and guaranteeing the state constraints. Denote the solution ξ = κ 1 , . . . , κ n-1 T for the optimization problem maximize P(ξ
div.formula: ) = n-1 i=1 κ i subject to k c i > A i-1 (ξ ), i = 2, . . . , n k i > 0, i = 1, . . . , n -1(49)
div.p: where A i-1 (ξ ) is defined in (45). The solution ξ * solved from the above offline optimization problem is feasible to guarantee the output tracking for the state-constrained nonlinear systems (1). As presented in [50], the use of iBLF in state-constrained systems has the advantages over the reduction of number of constraints in the optimization problem, i.e., the feasibility condition on k c i > A i-1 (ξ ) + k b i with k b i induced from transformed constraints on errors z i are eliminated, and the initial constrained states x have been expanded to any point in the constrained space χ .

div.head: VI. SIMULATION RESULTS
div.p: In this section, the performance of the proposed control is demonstrated on a single-link robotic manipulator with the inclusion of dc motor dynamics. In this case, the manipulator angle, angle velocity, as well as the motor current are constrained.
Consider a single-link manipulator with the inclusion of dc motor dynamics [8] given as
div.formula: M q + Dq + mgl sin q = k I I k m 1 İ + k m 2 I + k m 3 q = V + V d (50
div.p: where q is the manipulator joint angle, I is the motor current, V is the input voltage, V d is the disturbance in the input voltage, M is the inertia, D is damping coefficient, m denotes mass, l is the distance of the center of mass of the link from the joint, and k m i , i = 1, 2, 3, k I are positive constants in the electrical subsystem. By letting x 1 = q, x 2 = q, and x 3 = I, (50) can be expressed into the form (1) as
where
div.formula: f 2 = -sin(x 1 )mgl/M -x 2 D/M, g 2 = k I /M, f 3 = -x 2 k m 3 /k m 1 -x 3 k m 2 /k m 1 , g 3 = 1/k m 1 ,
div.p: In the simulation, the system parameters are m = 1 kg, l = 0.15 m, M = 1 kg•m 2 , D = 1, k I = 1, k m 1 = 0.05, k m 2 = 0.5, V d = sin(t), and k m 3 = 10. We choose ḡ1 (x 1 ) = ḡ2 (x 2 ) = ḡ3 (x 3 ) = 1 for control design, and since choosing ḡ3 (x 3 ) = 1 has violated Assumption 3, it is also used to check the robustness of the proposed control. The initial states are chosen in the predefined constrained state space [x 1 (0), x 2 (0), x 3 (0)] T = [0.2, 0.8, 0] T . Given the state constraints and initial states, we use the MATLAB command fmincon.m to perform the feasibility check, we obtain the optimal design parameters κ * 1 = 10.6275, κ * 2 = 8.0006, and choose κ 3 = 10.

The stabilization functions and final control input are designed as where z 1 = x 1y d , z 2 = x 2 -α 1 , and z 3 = x 3 -α 2 . The adaptive laws for the NN weights and adapting parameters are specified as

where the initial NN weight and adapting parameters are chosen as Ŵi (0) = 0 and pi (0) = 0, i = 1, 2, 3, respectively. To obtain good approximation performance, in particular, we set three nodes for each input dimension of ŴT 1 S 1 (Z 1 ), ŴT 2 S 2 (Z 2 ), and ŴT 3 S 3 (Z 3 ). Fig. 2 shows that the tracking objective is achieved without the violation of constraint on x 1 , and Fig. 3 shows the evolutions of state trajectories without the violation of constraints on states. The boundedness of NN estimation weights and adapting parameters are also presented in Figs. 4 and5, respectively. Fig. 6 shows the boundedness of control input, and the peaks in the initial control input are due to the system uncertainties and disturbances. Corresponding to the maximum obtained input value in Fig. 6, the maximum input voltage V is less than 12.5 V, which is near the nominal value for the IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON SYSTEMS, MAN, AND CYBERNETICS: SYSTEMS input voltage of commonly used market-available dc motor, and hence the proposed control is practical.

div.head: VII. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, we have presented control designs for state-constrained strict-feedback nonlinear systems with completely unknown system functions and unknown time-varying bounded disturbances. Novel iBLFs are employed to handle the unknown affine control gains and state constraints together. Adapting parameters have been developed to compensate the unknown bounds on NN approximations and disturbances. Compared with existing works, the proposed control has removed the need on the knowledge of control gains and bounds on NN approximation errors for control design. All closed-loop signals have been proved to be bounded, and state constraints are guaranteed provided that feasibility conditions are satisfied. Simulation results are given to demonstrate the effectiveness and performance of the proposed method.

Hence, the stabilizing functions α i and control input u are bounded as well by inspection of (38) with the boundedness of y d and its derivatives.
